properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of moderate snow is expected. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville-Makkovik. Time span: Monday through Wednesday. Snowfall today: 5 to 10 cm. Snowfall tonight: 5 to 10 cm. Snowfall Tuesday: 5 to 10 cm, with additional amounts likely Tuesday night and Wednesday. Remarks: A prolonged snowfall event is expected for northern Labrador for the next few days. While snowfall amounts are not expected to reach warning criteria the cumulative amounts may exceed 30 cm by mid week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-09T01:16:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-08T09:17:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2424045504.2021
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chill values between minus 50 and minus 55 continue. The coldest air is expected to move west of the Great Slave Lake area on Tuesday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-09T01:16:14-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:

Snowfall Tuesday and Tuesday night: 15 to 25 cm possible. Remarks: A prolonged snowfall event is expected for northern Labrador for the next few days. While snowfall amounts are not expected to reach warning criteria on Monday or Monday night they likely will on Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Lake effect flurries and local blowing snow continue tonight. An additional 5 cm of snow is expected tonight. Brisk westerly winds gusting up to 40 km/h may cause occasional low visibility at times in blowing snow. Poor winter driving conditions continue tonight. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. The lake effect snow will weaken into scattered flurries on Monday as the winds finally diminish. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T17:00:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-08T05:52:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2747113356.2021
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Flurries, heavy at times, will continue off of Lake Superior tonight. Snow squalls are forecast to move back into the area Monday morning. Snowfall amounts of 5 cm per 12 hours are likely with some localized areas getting up to 10 cm. Dangerous winter driving conditions in bursts of heavy snow and blowing snow will continue into Monday. Motorists are advised to adjust travel plans accordingly. Note that a snow squall watch has been issued for intensifying snow squalls Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T17:38:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-08T01:39:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2809252654.2021

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Lake effect flurries and local blowing snow continue tonight. An additional 5 cm of snow is expected tonight. Brisk westerly winds gusting up to 50 km/h will whip up freshly fallen snow and cause sudden very low visibility at times in blowing snow. Poor winter driving conditions continue tonight. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. The lake effect snow will weaken into scattered flurries on Monday as the winds finally diminish. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T15:59:56-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight. Snowfall accumulations of up to 15 cm are expected tonight as the snow squalls continue. The combination of winds gusting to 50 km/h and freshly fallen snow could result in near zero visibility in blowing snow. The heaviest snow squall activity will move out of the area on Monday as winds shift to southwesterly. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Arctic air over the northern and central Yukon will continue to give extreme cold through Tuesday morning. Over the next couple of nights, overnight lows are expected to be as cold as minus 45 C with wind chill values approaching minus 50 at times. Temperatures are forecast to slowly rise by midweek. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Arctic air continues to move throughout BC. Following a relatively mild first half of winter, a transition to much colder conditions continues throughout BC. Cold Arctic currently over the northern BC interior will continue to filter southwards and towards the BC coast. The Arctic air will arrive in the southern interior overnight or early Monday morning and reach the south coast Monday morning. On Tuesday, temperatures will continue to drop as more Arctic air is forced southwards. Strong outflow winds and brisk wind chill values are then expected to begin over southern coastal areas Tuesday night. Temperatures over Interior regions will be 10 to 20 degrees below the seasonal average, while coastal areas will be 5 to 10 degrees below seasonal, making for the coldest conditions seen this season. The cold air will persist for the remainder of the week. Arctic Outflow and Extreme Cold warnings are in effect for several regions in the province and may be expanded as the Arctic air progresses. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T15:59:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-08T00:00:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4056082364.2021
Area: Fraser Canyon - north including Lillooet, Fraser Canyon - south including Lytton, South Thompson, Nicola, Similkameen, North Okanagan - including Vernon, Central Okanagan - including Kelowna, South Okanagan - including Penticton, Shuswap, Arrow Lakes - Slocan Lake, Boundary, West Kootenay, Kootenay Lake, East Kootenay - south including Cranbrook, East Kootenay - north including Invermere, North Thompson, North Columbia, Kinbasket, West Columbia, East Columbia, Chilcotin, Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Cariboo - south including Williams Lake, 100 Mile, Yellowhead, Bulkley Valley, McGregor, Atlin
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. ### In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-09T00:22:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2021-02-08T01:27:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1567211364.2021
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continue tonight. Snow squalls will continue to affect the Bruce Peninsula tonight. 10 to 15 cm of additional snow will be possible. Snow squalls will weaken slowly to flurries on Monday as the winds diminish somewhat. Hazardous winter driving conditions from sudden very low visibility in bursts of heavy snow and occasional blowing snow will continue tonight before slowly improving Monday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T17:59:06-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off of Lake Superior possible on Monday. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to develop Monday morning as winds shift to a southwesterly direction. These snow squalls are then expected to continue into Monday night. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm per 12 hours are possible Monday and Monday night. Dangerous winter driving conditions will be possible Monday. Motorists are advised to adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Additional snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Locations: Queens and Kings counties. Time span: until this afternoon. Remarks: Northerly winds will further strengthen this morning giving near-zero visibilities at times in blowing and drifting snow. The snow will gradually ease this afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chill values of minus 40 to minus 45 tonight and Monday night. There will be some improvement during the afternoon as temperatures warm slightly, before temperatures fall again in the evening. The extreme cold may continue for the remainder of the week with wind chill values approaching minus 40 each night. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly changing to northwesterly 60 km/h. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: today and tonight. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin this morning, and become heavy, at times, by midday. Moderate winds in conjunction with the fresh snowfall will result in reduced visibility in blowing snow over some areas, especially tonight as northwesterly winds develop. The snow is expected to persist throughout the night and into Tuesday morning before tapering to flurries. The northwesterly winds will remain strong throughout the day Tuesday for areas along the northeast coast. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-09T00:15:46-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h except near 90 km/h along parts of the Atlantic coast. Locations: most of Nova Scotia. Time span: snow ending from west to east today. Remarks: Snow will taper off early this morning for western Nova Scotia. Strong winds, snow, and blowing snow are expected to persist for eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton into this afternoon. Additionally, higher than normal water levels are expected to occur near high tide early this morning along the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm continues. A weather disturbance moving across southern British Columbia will continue to bring snow to parts of the region. For Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, expect additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm before the snow eases to periods of light snow late this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T16:05:11-00:00

Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 35 cm, with the highest accumulations expected over the Connaigre and Burin peninsulas and in the Clarenville and Terra Nova areas. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 80 to 100 km/h becoming northwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: southern and eastern Newfoundland. Time span: today into Tuesday. Remarks: Snow has begun for southernmost regions, and will intensify and push north this morning. The snow combined with strong northeasterly winds this morning and strong northwesterly winds this afternoon and evening will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Over the Avalon, the snow will become mixed with ice pellets later this morning and is expected to change to rain or drizzle over some areas this afternoon. Conditions will improve overnight tonight for areas along the south coast as the snow tapers to flurries; however, strong northwesterly winds will persist into Tuesday afternoon which will may cause reduced visibility in blowing snow over some areas. Strong northwesterly winds and periods of snow will persist over more northern areas, including the St. John's Metro area, throughout the night and into Tuesday morning before tapering to onshore flurries. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-09T00:27:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-08T08:28:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1102193129.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off of Georgian Bay continue tonight. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible by Monday morning. Dangerous winter driving conditions are expected tonight, particularly along parts of highway 400 from near Mactier to just north of Parry Sound. Motorists are advised to adjust their travel plans accordingly. The lake effect snow will move to the north of the region and weaken into flurries beginning Monday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T20:04:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-08T08:16:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0970490875.2021
Area: Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Arctic Outflow Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong outflow winds and cold wind chill values are expected or occurring. Temperatures falling to the minus double digits will combine with winds of 30 to 50 km/h to generate wind chill values of -20 or lower across the North Coast Inland communities beginning tonight. Wind chill values may moderate towards the end of the week but uncertainty remains on the timing of the warm-up. ### Frostbite and hypothermia can occur within minutes if adequate precautions are not taken when outdoors. Arctic outflow warnings are issued when bitterly cold air flows from the interior to coastal communities and the outflow winds create wind chill values of -20 or less for 6 hours or more. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-08T17:30:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-08T01:31:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1290499310.2021
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm, with higher amounts possible over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland from Bay St. George to Hawke's Bay. Time span: beginning this morning and lasting into Tuesday. Remarks: Light snow is expected to spread across the west coast today, but will become heavier this evening as onshore winds develop. The onshore winds also have the potential to produce local snow squalls tonight and Tuesday. These strong winds will combine with fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibility in blowing snow. Conditions will improve for most areas Tuesday evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wave heights: 6 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: south-facing shorelines on the Burin and southern Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: this evening through Tuesday evening. Remarks: A passing storm will produce long period swells, with large breaking waves approaching the coast. Stay a safe distance away from the shoreline due to the rapid approach of large waves. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h except near 90 km/h along parts of the Atlantic coast. Locations: most of Nova Scotia. Time span: snow ending from west to east today. Remarks: Snow will taper off early this morning for western Nova Scotia. Strong winds, snow, and blowing snow are expected to persist for eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton into this afternoon. Additionally, higher than normal water levels are expected to occur near high tide early this morning along the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Arctic air over the area will give extreme cold through Tuesday morning. Over the next couple of nights, overnight lows are expected to drop to near minus 35 C with wind chill values approaching minus 40 at times. Temperatures are forecast to slowly rise by midweek. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
